site.title: What's Left Together
site.subtitle: What's Left Together
site.tagline: A statistical mirror of your time left with the people you love

hero.title: What's Left Together
hero.subtitle: A statistical mirror of how many times you might still see the people you love, if you keep living the way you do now.
hero.belowButton: We use official life tables by age and country, plus your current visiting habits, to estimate how many in-person moments you are likely to share from today on. It is not a prediction. It is a wake-up call.

calculator.title: Calculator
calculator.subtitle: Complete the information to calculate expected encounters
calculator.frequency: How many times you see each other in person per year, on average
calculator.frequencyNote: Includes visits, trips, weekends together, but not video calls.
calculator.frequencyPeriodLabel: How often do you see each other?
calculator.directMode: I want to see the result in direct mode
calculator.directModeHelp: Direct mode uses the same calculation, but with blunter language.

normalMode.title: If everything stays the same, you might see {relation} about {min} to {max} more times in your life.
normalMode.explanation:
According to life expectancy data for {country} and both of your ages, it is reasonable to expect that you will both be alive, at the same time, for about {yearsMin} to {yearsMax} more years.

If you see {relation} {frequency} times per year, that translates to an approximate range of {min} to {max} future in-person visits.

This is only a statistical estimate. It doesn't know either person's actual health, accidents, or life changes. But it does show you something true: the number is not infinite.
normalMode.actionTitle: You can decide what to do with this information.
normalMode.action2: Extend the time spent together on each visit
normalMode.action3: Or simply stop postponing an important conversation

directMode.title: At this rate, you don't have many visits left with {relation}.
directMode.mainStat: If nothing changes, you will likely only see {relation} about {min} to {max} more times in your entire life.
directMode.closing: This is not a threat or a medical prognosis. It is arithmetic applied to real mortality data. You decide what you do with that today.

results.timeAlreadySpentPercent: ~{percent}% of typical time together already lived

assumptions.title: What we calculate and what we don't
assumptions.what: Expected in-person visits between two people, based on life tables by age, sex, and country.
assumptions.point1: It doesn't predict when anyone will die
assumptions.point2: It shouldn't be used for medical decisions
assumptions.point3: It doesn't know specific illnesses or individual factors
assumptions.point4: Visit frequency is assumed stable (in real life it can change)

section1.title: 1. What we calculate
section1.text: Expected in-person visits remaining between two people.

section2.title: 2. Where the data comes from
section2.text: Life tables by age, country, and sex from the United Nations (World Population Prospects 2024) and the World Health Organization.

section3.title: 3. What assumptions we make
section3.text: Visit frequency remains stable. We don't incorporate specific illnesses or individual factors.

section4.title: 4. What this tool doesn't do
section4.text: It doesn't predict when anyone will die. It shouldn't be used for medical decisions.

section5.title: 5. Why we believe showing this number is useful
section5.text: People tend to underestimate how finite their time with others is. A concrete number helps make more conscious decisions about priorities.

why.title: Why It Matters
why.intro: When we perceive time as limited, we prioritize what truly matters.

section1.title: Time passes without us noticing
section1.text: Data from the American Time Use Survey shows that most time with parents is concentrated before age 20. After that, frequency drops dramatically.

section2.title: Socioemotional Selectivity Theory
section2.text: When we perceive that time is limited, we prioritize close relationships and emotional goals over exploration. (Carstensen, 1999)

section3.title: Not to scare, but to act
section3.text: The goal isn't to create anxiety, but to make explicit a reality that usually remains abstract. With that information, you can decide better.

ethical.notMedical: This tool is NOT medical advice or an individual prediction.
ethical.is1: An approximation based on population averages
ethical.is3: A reminder of the finite nature of time
ethical.is4: A starting point for conscious prioritization
ethical.useResponsibly: Use it responsibly: as a tool for reflection, not distress. As a motivator for positive action (more time together), not resignation.
ethical.seekSupport: If you experience anxiety when using this tool, seek emotional support from trusted people or professionals.
ethical.understood: I understand and accept to continue

purpose.title: Why this tool exists
purpose.p1: What's Left Together was born from a personal reflection: we often take for granted that we'll have "time later" to see the important people in our lives.
purpose.p2: Physical distance, work obligations, and the inertia of daily life make us postpone visits, calls, or simply being present. We assume there will always be a next time.
purpose.p3: This tool doesn't aim to scare, but to make explicit something that normally remains abstract: if we keep living as we do now, with the same frequency of encounters, how many more times will we actually see each other?

inspiration.title: Inspiration
inspiration.p1: This project is inspired by Tim Urban's article "The Tail End" (Wait But Why, 2015), which visualizes the time remaining with loved ones in a visceral and memorable way.
inspiration.p2: Unlike that article, which uses generic estimates, this tool incorporates official demographic data by age, country, and sex, to make the estimate more precise and personalized.

card1.title: People who live far from their family
card1.text: If you emigrated, study in another city, or life simply took you away from your parents, siblings, or loved ones.

card2.title: Those prioritizing career or personal goals
card2.text: If you're focused on professional development or personal projects and feel that "there will be time later" for family visits.

card3.title: People in long-distance relationships
card3.text: If you maintain a romantic relationship, deep friendship, or mentorship from afar, and want to reflect on the value of shared time.

card4.title: Researchers and educators
card4.text: As an educational tool about demography, life tables, or psychology of temporal perception.

whatToDo.title: What to do with this information
whatToDo.intro: The goal is not to generate anxiety, but clarity.

action1.title: Prioritize:
action1.text: You might decide to increase visit frequency, take that trip you've been postponing, or simply call more often.

action2.title: Reflect:
action2.text: You might realize that the current balance satisfies you, and that's valid too.

action3.title: Plan:
action3.text: If the number surprises you, you can use it as motivation to reorganize priorities or negotiate more flexible work arrangements.

action4.title: Share:
action4.text: Sometimes, showing this number to the other person can open important conversations about what you both value.

ethics.title: Important ethical limits
ethics.warningTitle: This tool should NOT be used for:
ethics.warning1: Making medical or life insurance decisions
ethics.warning2: Pressuring others to change their behavior
ethics.warning4: Individual predictions about when someone will die
ethics.warning5: Any commercial use without explicit authorization
ethics.note: If you feel persistent anxiety after using this tool, consider talking to a mental health professional. Numbers should not replace self-care.
